Antenna is a short and simple puzzle game with a very unique art style that seems to derive from games like LIMBO and Closure. The story is pretty simple, you play as a lonely robot in a world unknown, and your objective is to contact someone out there, using the radio towers and other equipment the robot hopes to find someone out there, anyone out there. The puzzles are pretty simple once you realize how to solve them, and the atmosphere and sound in the game is quite pleasing to go along with the simple game play. I do really wish there was a bit more to this game, because it's fantastic, unfortunately it's very short and doesn't have a lot to offer. reviewText:
Product received for free

I don't get it. Am I missing something? I think I'm missing something. I mean, it really feels like I'm missing something. I've definitely gotta be missing something... right?

Antenna is a short, free, 2D game based largely around audio puzzles. Follow some on-screen button prompts to raise and activate antennae, scan the frequencies for the correct audio, traipse around as a weird, four-legged spider drone thingy, do a couple more audio puzzles, see a picture of a planet slowly become ever so slightly more distant, have the game shut itself down on you, then scratch your head and wonder what the hell you just played. There, I've saved you half an hour of having to play this yourself.

Maybe some will brand me a philistine, but I just don't get what the point of this thing is. There's no explanation given to anything in the game; no real clear objective for any of the puzzles, no set-up for who, what, why or where exactly you are, no form of context for anything at all, it's all just... stuff. Formless, meaningless stuff. I guess all just... because. I know brevity is the soul of wit an' all, but c'mon, would it have really hurt to provide even the slightest form of basic insight into anything? Maybe they hope the environment or apparent scenario will lead us to question everything and make us create our own story, but that really feels lazy if that's actually the case. That's why I almost feel like there must be some kind of inside info I'm somehow completely missing. Everyone likes a bit of mystery, but the joy of that comes from teasing us with a little information then having us chase after the rest of the answers that will eventually come. Here, there's just nothing - nothing teased, nothing to chase, just... nothing.

I guess the actual audio design itself is pretty well done, and the minimal, heavy-silhouetted visuals are as appealing as they've always been, but personally that doesn't count for very much when the gameplay itself is so lacking. I feel like someone's given me a single paragraph from a novel but then denied me the rest of the book, and by the end I was mostly just annoyed and left empty by the lack of direction or context.

If you feel like you haven't been especially catered for in the audio puzzle department and have been looking for something to fill that void, this may give you a little kick while it lasts. For everyone else, I honestly don't know what this has to offer you.

reviewText:
It's free, and that very apparent, its noted in every review as a reason to appease the game for being technically awful. It takes an age to load, if you try and skip the opening 'cinematic' it will freeze for infinity, when you're in the game it will crash and without checkpoints you have to start over and the 'puzzles' are buggy. There is a four square puzzle relies on sound distinction (Always a bad choice as all audio setups are VERY different) and the way of manipulating it gives very little feedback and is tedious to control. I got past the puzzle after that which again is about ascending notes so not such a problem, but then the game crashed again. That marked my fifth attempt to just play the game and I had gotten bored of a robot spider moving at half a mile an hour toward half baked puzzles. The art style is ok, but derivative, I would say best described as limbo style sillohettes meets a near future apocolypse setting, however in contrast the coding and puzzle design are incredibly poor. This urges the question of 'why play this?' the answer is there is not a single reason. If you want something like this then I would recommend Limbo. It is far more thought out, doesn't crash, has puzzles that work as such, in short it is everything this game tries to be but fails to reach. I hope the developer of this is not too discouraged as it has potential, but it needs to be more thought out, and a some Q/A to be worth your time.


TL;DR
Game is broken both in mechanics and through bugs, if you want this but thought out then play Limbo.

It's beautiful (grats, artist!), but it's really, really bad. I wish I hadn't tried it. STAY AWAY! It's not worth your time! I wouldn't accept getting paid $1 to play this again.

2) Hold shift+right to walk for a few minutes.
3) A few more buttons and hold shift+left for a few minutes.
4) Make a detour, walk right for a while.
5) Solve an ok puzzle, then walk to the right a bit more.
6) Solve one the most illogical puzzle where you can barely hear the sounds you're supposed to make sense of.
7) Instead of seeing the end and getting the final achievement, watch the game crash.
8) Repeat steps 1-7, but only once.
9) Be nice to your friends and leave a negative review so they don't fall into the same trap.

In the end, this is just a walking simulator disguised as an adventure game, and it's just dumb.

reviewText:
It's free. It's unusual. It's kind of pretty if sillouettes are your thing.

That's where the good ends.

I liked The Plan, but this game - while having more elements of a game than The Plan - feels like less of a game.

Essentially, you press keys when they tell you and occassionally face a pretty simple puzzle or a puzzle that more or less relies on dumb luck. There's no story. The cool premise you see in the description is all the story you get. If there was no description, then you wouldn't know about a machine pondering its lonliness, much less a question. The game goes nowhere in terms of story and is basic and at times frustratingly slow in terms of gameplay. It's free, though, and the art is interesting (both visuals and sound design).

Give it a try, I guess, but I think this could have been good had it been a little less postmodern or a whole lot more postmodern. As it is, it is pointless as a game and as art. You might like pointless, and it's not bad, but that's where it is.

Also, it was laggy and even buggy at times, which is inexcusable for a basic game like this.

Good things:
+This game is FREE.
+The controls are good (if you can figure them out and figuring the controls out is part of the game)
+The sound is truly excellent. It is atmospheric and haunting and creepy. The shortwave radio frequency sounds are particularly amazing and creepy.

Mediocre Things:
+/-There are not very many puzzles.
+/-The graphics are highly unique. Everything is portrayed as shadows and silhouettes. The graphics add to it but at once tell you frustratingly little about what is happening.

Bad things:
-Very short game and some puzzles can be a little obtuse, especially if you are not used to the kind of puzzles which commonly occur in mystery games. By very short I mean that this game lasted about 50 minutes for me and I got every single steam achievement this game has.
-This game lacks any replayability whatsoever. This game is an experimental experience more than an actual game.
-Not knowing what this game is about is very frustrating.

One thing I need to point out is that the puzzles are sound based, hence the theme of Antenna! You need to listen carefully to get through the puzzles.

It is really short once you know how to puzzle it out, like with most fixed puzzle games, but with such games it is not for the impatient when first playing through it. A game of fine tuning.
A short simple game where you are some kind of robot searching for a signal on a mysterious world.  The ambience and visuals in this game really hits the spot, and brings a very LIMBO environment, however some of the frequencies are quite painful to the ear for long periods of time. It's just a really dull drone that's not for everyone.

Overall, this is not a difficult game for those fellow fine tuners out there, and if you're looking for some easy achievements to accomplish, this will be the game. There is no storyline or plot or reason behind what you are doing, so if you are here for the plot - probably best to find another game...

It wasn't a bad game at all. I wouldn't call it GOTY worthy, but this game has a certain desolate land feel to it. No backstory, no real objective except to (sit down for this one folks...) restore signal by initializing antennas. Somehow this game invokes my thoughts (as a good indie game would), it makes me question things such as:

Where is this little robot sent from?
Why do they need these signals to be up?
There are still humans speaking over these frequencies you can slowly tune into, if that's the case why is this robot sent in to fix this problem?
There is a lack of life yet trees are seen in the backgrounds (What kind of Earth is this?)
Overall, I would say this game is a good time killer. Replayability isn't so high up there, but it definitely is a worthy experience. It is a very small environment, but it still captivates me tremendously. Most of the negative reviews on this game are people who expect big action-packed, story driven, colorful, indie games. I believe this one is worth checking out. And after all, it is free.
